4.23.text:
Ms. Morrison:
Hello, my name
is Natalie Morrison.

5.29.text: Welcome to Ask the White House,

7.13.text:
brought to you
by Skype and Bing.

9.59.text:
This is your chance
to ask questions

11.33.text:
to the people that matter
in the administration.

14.13.text:
Now the White House has selected
the discussion topic today,

17.23.text:
so it will be their policy
views that we are discussing.

20.49.text:
Skype's role here
is to simply facilitate

22.80.text:
the conversation between
the American people

28.93.text:
And joining me to do so,
we have Cecilia Munoz.

31.66.text:
She is the director to
the Domestic Policy Council.

34.83.text:
And we also have
Vice President Joe Biden.

37.09.text:
Thank you so much
both for joining me.

39.90.text:
The Vice President:
Delight to be with you.

42.16.text:
Now the Vice President
and Ms. Munoz

43.26.text:
will be taking questions
from callers via Skype.

45.90.text:
But you can join the
conversation as well,

47.66.text:
if you'd like to
do so on Twitter.

51.46.text:
Now before we take any live
questions, we'd like to ask you,

54.13.text:
Mr. Vice President,
why is immigration

56.13.text: such an important topic to you?

57.86.text:
The Vice President:
You know, at its core,

59.06.text:
immigration is all about
what's built America.

62.06.text:
I was recently --
I've been in Asia.

63.96.text:
And if I sound
particularly tired,

65.39.text:
it's because I'm just
recently gotten back.

68.49.text:
And I met with one
of the wisest men

71.39.text:
according to most
heads of state.

78.80.text: He's a man of great wisdom.

80.96.text: And I met with him in Singapore.

82.56.text:
And I asked him what
was going on in China.

84.66.text: He's an expert in the region.

86.53.text:
And I -- he said, "The Chinese
are in America looking

89.59.text:
for the black box that's
buried in America."

92.70.text:
And I looked at him,
and I said,

95.70.text:
He said,
"That thing that allows America

98.49.text:
to be the only country
in the world that constantly

103.26.text:
And I said, "Oh, I can tell
him what's in that black box:

111.06.text:
That's what makes us
the most innovative,

113.70.text:
the most unique
country in the world."

115.96.text:
And so at its core,
we're a nation of immigrants.

118.96.text:
And there's 11 million people
who are in a sense already

122.53.text:
Americans because they've
already adopted the values.

130.86.text:
And it's time to be
taken out of the shadows.

132.99.text:
And what we've been pushing,
the president and Cecilia,

136.53.text:
is about our main
point person on this,

138.83.text:
is a rational policy to allow
these 11 million people to come

143.13.text:
out of the shadows and have an
opportunity to earn the right

149.63.text:
And it is not only the
morally right thing to do.

153.66.text: It's not only in our interest.

155.29.text:
It's the thing that will
allow us to continue to grow.

157.43.text:
And it will save us billions
and billions of dollars.

161.49.text:
It's estimated that the --
that our GDP will increase

165.23.text:
by over 5.3 percent,
something like that.

169.49.text:
The Vice President:
And 1 point something
trillion dollars.

173.76.text:
And Social Security will be
made stronger, not weaker,

176.80.text:
because more people
we paying into it.

178.39.text:
So there's a whole lot
of reasons to do it,

180.66.text:
but the fundamental reason is
it's the right thing to do.

183.76.text: It's the fair thing to do.

185.09.text: It's the decent thing to do.

186.59.text: We're all, all of us here,

188.73.text:
are sons and daughters
of immigrants.

191.16.text:
Ms. Morrison:
Thank you for that.

192.53.text:
And obviously this is -- very
emotional and polarizing issue.

195.06.text:
So we're going to take our
first live Skype caller.

198.09.text:
Joining us now
is Crystal Wright,

200.99.text: and she is joining us via Skype.

205.49.text:
but she is also the
conservative black chick.

210.83.text:
That's the name of
her blog as well.

212.49.text:
Crystal, thank you
for joining us.

215.59.text:
Ms. Wright:
Well, thank you
Mr. Vice President,

219.19.text:
I do agree that this
is an important topic

222.90.text:
And I am the granddaughter
of an immigrant.

225.36.text:
And my question is do you really
think it's fair to grant amnesty

229.53.text:
to over 11 million people who
came to our country illegally

233.80.text:
with so many others --
millions, in fact --

236.49.text:
wait their turn
to come to America.

240.16.text:
The Vice President:
Well, we're not
granting amnesty.

241.53.text:
They're going to
have to get in line.

243.13.text:
They have to get in line in
order to earn that citizenship.

246.39.text:
And it's a long line, and it's
going to take a long time.

249.53.text:
It takes 10 years or
thereabouts for that to happen.

252.13.text:
In the meantime,
they'll be paying taxes.

254.33.text:
They'll have safer neighborhoods
because you'll find people being

258.23.text:
willing to report crime
and they're afraid to now

260.59.text:
because they're afraid
they'll be deported

262.23.text: if they are victims of crime.

263.99.text:
And they report it, you'll find
them contributing more

266.59.text:
to the economic base
of this country.

269.36.text:
So it's not -- they're not
being granted amnesty.

271.53.text: They have to earn their way.

272.80.text:
They have to learn to speak
English, pay all back taxes,

275.13.text:
have a background
checks, et cetera.

277.09.text:
And so we don't
see it as amnesty.

281.53.text:
And it's the only
way to get right

285.63.text:
there are people
waiting in line.

287.49.text:
We have to reform the
existing system as well.

297.23.text:
and it's not very
clear how it works.

300.09.text:
And so that's part of
the reform as well.

302.06.text:
Ms. Munoz: Well, and I would
just add there are economic

303.80.text:
benefits that accrue to all
Americans as a result

305.83.text:
of passing, certainly
with the Senate bill passed.

308.43.text:
You'll hear the Vice President
talk about how it grows GDP

310.56.text: and it ends up creating jobs

311.90.text:
for everybody else,
helping us grow our economy.

314.26.text:
So it's not only
is it not unfair,

316.80.text:
it helps the rest of the
country, helps grow our economy,

319.29.text:
helps create jobs
for everybody else.

320.99.text:
The Vice President:
And an awful lot of those folks

322.96.text:
in the shadows now didn't
-- are young people.

327.56.text:
And they didn't say,
"By the way, hey, Mom and Dad,

332.99.text: I don't want to be part of this.

335.19.text: I mean, they had no choice.

338.03.text:
They're living in the
community, they're law-abiding,

340.36.text:
they're moving forward,
they're getting an education.

342.99.text:
And so it seems to me the
only way to do this fairly

347.56.text:
and humanely and to the
benefit of all of us.

353.09.text:
Crystal, thank you so much
for that response then --

355.09.text:
The
Vice President: You don't sound
so conservative to me, Crystal.

357.46.text:
Ms. Morrison:
Maybe we'll read her blog

358.76.text:
and see what she
has to say in response.

361.36.text: But we have to move on.

365.53.text:
And I do agree, though, that
young children who were brought

367.83.text:
here as infants, you know, we
have to find to deal with that.

371.46.text:
And also, I like
the fact that you want

372.83.text:
to enforce the law
that's on the book.

374.59.text:
I'm an advocate for that,
and I do think that, you know,

377.13.text:
I have friends who waited
long and hard and brought

379.86.text:
family members here,
and waited a number of years

382.23.text:
and didn't just cross
the border illegally.

384.63.text:
So I just have an
ethical problem with it.

386.63.text:
But I appreciate your
response, Mr. Vice President.

388.63.text:
The Vice President:
Thank you very much.

389.99.text:
Ms. Morrison:
And like I said,

391.33.text:
I'm sure she'll have more to say
on conservativeblackchick.com.

395.16.text:
We're going to move
on and take a video message

398.39.text: This one is from Jessica Ives.

402.39.text:
And what I would
like to know is,

404.03.text:
if we know that immigration
reform will improve our economy

407.90.text:
and make us more competitive
in the global market,

410.56.text:
then why is it so hard to
push it through Congress?

414.70.text:
The Vice President:
Well, that's a
really good question.

416.70.text:
First of all, the one
thing I wanted to point out

420.26.text:
is Natalie said this
is very controversial.

422.26.text:
It's controversial,
but the vast majority

423.96.text:
of the American
people support this.

426.19.text:
This is not something that we're
pushing, you know, where --

429.49.text:
this is not like
pushing a rope.

431.06.text:
What we have is a dedicated and
decent group of Americans

434.66.text:
who are a minority, saying,
"We don't want this to happen."

441.86.text:
Throughout our entire history,
we've gone through these periods

444.19.text:
where there are
groups and elements

446.86.text:
within the community that
say, "Enough. We're here.

452.83.text:
And so I don't --
look, the one --

456.33.text:
there's an easy thing
that can happen.

458.59.text:
Even the majority of
the members of Congress,

462.96.text:
believe there's a
need for this reform.

465.23.text:
But Mr. Boehner,
who's a good man,

467.36.text:
the speaker of the
House of Representatives,

469.16.text:
he will not call up the bill,
passed overwhelmingly

473.63.text:
by the Senate --
Democrats and Republicans --

477.26.text:
a truly bipartisan
measure that has enough votes

480.93.text:
in the United States House
of Representative to pass.

483.73.text:
He will not bring it
up because he is very worried

486.46.text:
about his very conservative
base, his Tea Party base,

490.70.text:
and he's unwilling
to let the House speak.

494.43.text:
He's unwilling to
let the House vote.

496.90.text:
There's only one thing
that has to be done.

499.06.text:
John Boehner, call up the Senate
bill, the bipartisan bill.

508.90.text:
is this something that
people ask you as well?

512.86.text:
Ms. Munoz:
Yeah, this is the question
of the hour with this

514.63.text:
is an issue where, as the
Vice President has said,

519.73.text:
We can see the finish
line, but the thing between us

521.93.text:
and the finish line,
as the Vice President says,

524.06.text:
there's the speaker
of the House,

526.70.text:
We know that if a bill that's
like the Senate bill came up

528.76.text:
on the floor,
that it would pass.

530.26.text:
This isn't a question about
getting the votes anymore.

532.13.text:
It's a question about
a process to get to a vote.

535.43.text:
And there is a tremendous
amount of pressure --

538.70.text:
a lot of voices from
all around the country --

540.43.text: in what is really the broadest

542.59.text:
and deepest coalition
that I've ever seen.

544.99.text:
It includes faith
leaders of every kind.

547.53.text:
It includes business
leaders of every kind.

551.59.text:
It includes leaders of
state and local governments,

553.66.text:
all of whom are
saying the same thing,

556.66.text:
which is that this
system is broken,

558.99.text: and we know how to fix it,

560.26.text:
and all we need
Congress to do is vote.

562.83.text:
So I believe we will get there,
and we will certainly keep

566.06.text:
pushing until we get
there, no question.

567.63.text:
The Vice President:
So I think the
way we'll get there

571.33.text:
to push their
members of Congress.

573.63.text:
Look, there is, you know
that old expression,

575.73.text: the tail is wagging the dog?

577.39.text:
There's a very --
there's a minority

579.83.text:
within the majority
of the House.

584.53.text:
Somewhere between 75
and 110 out of the 230-some

590.59.text:
or whatever that actual
number is, who just are --

594.53.text:
do not want to see
immigration, period.

597.73.text:
And it's not just
immigration reform.

599.39.text:
I mean, they've not
supported more immigration.

602.46.text:
And so right now,
they are the controlling voice

609.70.text:
I'm going to be
very blunt with you.

611.33.text:
You see very conservative United
States senators who are

615.19.text:
Republicans being primaried
by these very people because

621.99.text:
I mean, Ronald Reagan
wouldn't have passed the test

624.33.text:
that these guys
are applying now.

626.36.text:
And so the vast majority of
Republicans and Democrats think

635.93.text:
but John Boehner just
has to call the vote.

641.66.text:
Now we have a tweet
from username dramatbarzo,

647.49.text:
Is that either
of your Twitter friends?

650.43.text:
Vice President
Biden: I don't know.

654.46.text:
What will the
employment outlook be --

656.96.text:
when 11 million new
legals enter the workforce,

660.33.text:
question
mark and two exclamation points.

664.19.text:
The Vice President:
Two exclamation points.

666.29.text: So he wants a real answer.

667.63.text:
The Vice President:
What's going to
happen is pay levels

670.80.text:
The Vice President:
And here's why
they're going to go up.

672.13.text:
There's a lot of these folks who
are living in the shadows now

675.19.text:
that are being exploited by
employers who know they can pay

680.63.text:
them less than the
minimum wage or pay them

685.59.text:
But once they are
out of the shadows,

688.23.text:
they're no longer able
to do that under the law.

691.13.text:
They won't -- well, not able
to do this under the law now.

693.63.text:
And what's happened is, and
we'll raise the level of all

696.43.text:
people making money,
because they will not be able

699.46.text:
to go out and
hire people at a wage

705.16.text:
in legally hiring
them to do that.

707.96.text:
And so it will actually
raise the wages.

710.49.text:
And a lot of these people
are working already.

712.63.text:
Ms. Munoz:
And we can -- we know we
cannot quantify by how much.

715.19.text:
Economists generally agree
that immigrants are good

717.76.text:
for the United States,
but now we have a Senate bill.

719.83.text:
We measure the
Congressional Budget Office,

722.53.text:
which is a non-partisan body,
has measured what the economic

726.70.text:
And what they found, as you
heard the Vice President say,

728.49.text:
that that bill will grow GDP
by more than 5 percent --

734.13.text:
That means more
jobs for everybody.

735.80.text:
And wages for the average
American worker go up

738.13.text: as a result of this bill.

740.29.text:
The Vice President:
And also points out --

741.66.text:
I just want to get

743.59.text:
Eight hundred --
and we'll reduce the deficit

748.99.text:
$300 billion more will be put in

754.56.text:
And it extends the

758.09.text:
So in every measure, every
measure it will be better

764.43.text:
natural born American
citizens working right now.

768.23.text:
They will not be
able to be undercut.

770.73.text:
- Right. And that's important
that we all know those numbers

772.86.text:
then so that it
influences our community

776.80.text:
We have another live Skype call
coming to us from New Jersey.

784.49.text:
Ms. Morrison:
Steve has an interesting
perspective on immigration.

787.33.text:
He writes the blog Waiter Rant,
which was also a New York Times

792.56.text:
So he speaks on behalf
of his colleagues.

794.53.text:
Steve, why don't you tell
us your question, please.

796.26.text:
Steve Dublanica:
Well, hello, Mr. Vice
President, Mrs. Munoz.

800.13.text:
I worked in the restaurant
business for nine years,

802.76.text:
an industry where it's
conservatively estimated

805.43.text:
that 1 in 10 employees
are undocumented immigrants.

809.63.text:
Because of their status,
they're frequently

819.49.text:
The Vice President:
Take your time, old buddy.

820.66.text:
Steve Dublanica:
In my experience, these busboys,

821.93.text:
cooks, and waiters aren't always
interested in citizenship.

825.06.text:
But they are hardworking, honest
people who just want to be left

828.03.text:

832.03.text:
Is there any way the

834.49.text:

839.09.text:

844.49.text:
Ms. Munoz:
For workers who

so that they have

That's not only how

They will --

It's -- but --

so that they can benefit from

878.13.text:
the same labor laws that protect

881.03.text:
And it's in our

886.06.text:
The Vice President:
I think she's answered

What part of New

Steve Dublanica:
Right by Giant Stadium,

895.23.text:
The Vice President:
The home of the Super Bowl.

899.49.text:
Ms. Morrison:
Beyond the scope

Steve, thank you

903.06.text:
And it's very sweet that we have

904.86.text:
to speak on behalf of your

906.63.text: who don't have the same rights.

Let's take another

this one from Scott
Elsinbine has this question.

913.86.text:
- Hi, my name is Scott,

our investment in their

923.49.text:
The Vice President:
I'm not sure I got that.

925.56.text:
Ms. Munoz:
I think this is
about making sure

929.93.text:
So we're -- you're --
the DREAMers that we've talked

932.66.text:
about, young folks who were

937.03.text:
They were brought here
when they were small.

938.63.text:

944.09.text:

That's how you return

950.46.text:
The Vice President:
And the best

And that's not denying

962.63.text:

965.99.text:

they're going to be the

970.06.text:
They're going to be the people

973.53.text:
They may come up
with the new way to be able

978.70.text:
I mean, there's a lot
of potential here,

982.86.text:
And it just
seems to me -- to us --

985.19.text:
foolhardy that if
they've played by the rules,

988.26.text:
they've done well,
they're in school,

990.36.text:

995.33.text:

you have no idea

1012.63.text:

so that's why that

1018.83.text:

Ms. Morrison:
Anneal is the -- oh, I'm sorry.

He's the CEO of a new

1044.63.text:
employers are expected to use
to verify that their employees

1052.33.text:
It has so much potential to help

1054.73.text:
really connect to a lot
of new opportunities,

1057.56.text:
but there's some justifiable
skepticism about the federal

1064.16.text:

right and works correctly right
away and serves all of these

1083.83.text:
undocumented folks and taps

in the tech industry

1089.09.text:
Ms. Munoz:
Anneal, this is
a great question.

1091.59.text:
So for folks who may not

it is a verification system that
